abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project for the Kyrgyz Republic received a
            moderately satisfactory outcome rating with substantial risk
            to development outcome. The Bank received a satisfactory
            rating for its performance while the Borrowers’ performance
            was rated moderately satisfactory. The project underwent
            three restructurings. The first restructuring transferred
            project executing and implementing responsibilities to a new
            entity due to non-performance of original entities. The
            second restructuring address a series of implementation and
            sector challenges; changes were made to the PDO and other
            aspects, such as scope, results framework, expenditure
            categories, and safeguard policies. The third and final
            restructuring optimized the scope of investments in light of
            a funding shortfall; also to allow for reallocation of funds
            among categories, mobilization of US$500,000 in additional
            co-financing by the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic
            (GoKR), and adjustments to the result framework. Several
            lessons were learned from this project including the
            following: (1) design of so called ‘repeater’ or follow-on
            operations should involve comprehensive consultations with
            various key stakeholders to capture any legacy issues and
            incorporate important lessons on what has and has not worked
            at different stages of the original project, (2) design of
            project implementation arrangements should hinge on building
            robust institutional structures that can withstand internal
            and external shocks such as the withdrawal of individual
            champions or changes in government, (3) strengthening local
            engineering-design capacities and standards should be an
            important element of capacity building efforts to enhance
            the technical sustainability of water supply and sanitation
            infrastructure investments, (4) sustained Bank engagement
            and support to client governments in the face of serious
            sector challenges can enable an improbable project
            turnaround and gradual rebuild of sector capacities, (5)
            bank teams should manage expectations and ensure that
            sufficient and meaningful dialogue is maintained with all
            key stakeholders prior to and throughout project
            implementation, and finally (6) project implementation
            arrangements should always be designed to strengthen
            internal Government capacity.
